brief_description of the content in the: The JetBrains Inspectopedia page describes a rule that checks for inconsistencies in @AspectJ Introduction. Specifically, it verifies if the defaultImpl is required and if so, whether it implements the given interface.
generated_rule_explanation from GPT-4: The rule 'declare_parents_inspection' checks all classes in the project. If a class has the '@AspectJ' annotation, it then checks all methods within that class. If a method has the 'declare parents' annotation, it retrieves the 'defaultImpl' attribute from the annotation. If 'defaultImpl' is not empty, it asserts that a class with the name 'defaultImpl' exists and that it implements the interface that is the return type of the method. If this assertion fails, it generates a message indicating the inconsistency.
PRE_model_validation: The generated rule is syntactically correct and follows the RSL syntax. It uses only the built-in functions and does not introduce any new ones. The rule checks for the existence of a class, checks for annotations, retrieves annotation attributes, checks if a class implements an interface, and generates a message if the assertion fails.
3rd-party most relevant URLs and summary:
1. URL: https://www.baeldung.com/aspectj - This page provides a comprehensive guide to AspectJ, including introductions and the 'declare parents' annotation. It explains how to use AspectJ to implement cross-cutting concerns in a Java application.

2. URL: https://www.eclipse.org/aspectj/doc/released/progguide/semantics-declare.html - This page from the official AspectJ documentation explains the semantics of the 'declare' statement, including 'declare parents'. It provides examples and explains the implications of using 'declare parents'.
